4. **Educating Them**: If you do decide to come out, you might need to gently correct their misconceptions about bisexuality. For example, you could explain that bisexuality is about attraction to more than one gender, not about ‚Äúdoing anything.‚Äù However, this is not your responsibility if it feels too overwhelming.

5. **Setting Boundaries**: If their comments continue to make you uncomfortable, it‚Äôs okay to set boundaries. You can say something like, ‚ÄúI feel uncomfortable when people say things like that about bisexuality,‚Äù even if you‚Äôre not ready to come out.

6. **Safety**: If you‚Äôre unsure how they‚Äôll react or worry about your safety or living situation, it might be best to wait until you‚Äôre in a more secure position to come out.

Remember, your identity is valid, and you deserve to be surrounded by people who respect and celebrate who you are. If coming out to your parents feels too risky right now, that‚Äôs okay‚Äîyou can choose to share this part of yourself with them when the time feels right.

Context: I've been going through a rough time lately. I been into nothing but women. I‚Äôve never thought about men until a week ago. I‚Äôm very upset and depressed about this. It's not normal to me. I looked at gay porn more than once to prove that I‚Äôm not gay. I get the same results each time, and I feel disgust. This is tough on me. I'm scared that I looked too many times. I keep thinking about it and shake all the time.
Response: Hello. Coming to terms with the idea that you might be of a sexuality other than the one in which you were socially raised to be, can be emotionally disturbing, and quite unsettling. It creates anxiety, maybe even panic, and leaves us feeling confused and uncertain about our own sense of identity. It becomes important to first ask yourself how you feel when you are thinking of being intimate with guys, or if you desire them to be intimate with you. It is important to know what impact this has on you, because it can determine your level of follow through and desire in pursuing sexual activity with someone of the same sex. I am not going to pass judgment on you either way - even for having the thoughts. I have worked with the lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, queer (LGBTQ) community in various ways over the years. Many I speak to, say they had to struggle to come to terms with this awareness about how they see themselves sexually. Maybe you are bisexual, and don't have an exclusive attraction to the same sex. You might consider doing some searches online for community support groups in your area, to explore the feelings and issues around this topic. Talking to someone who you trust can be helpful too. Running from your feelings is not a good idea, and others in a support group for sexuality issues, might be able to relate to you and what you're going through right now. This will offer you perspective, as you think on how this plays out in your life.Counselors are typically well trained to provide clinical services to clients who are experiencing feelings and thoughts much like the ones you are having now. I encourage you to consider reaching out for help. You are not crazy or insane for thinking of working with a counselor, nor of having feelings of same sex attraction. If you decide you are indeed gay, then know that you are not alone and never will be alone in that feeling. There is a huge community of support for you. Additionally, we all need help sometimes dealing with all sort of issues. A counselor can work more in depth with you to examine the motivations behind the feelings, and help you come to terms with them more directly. I hope that you come to a place where you feel less alone and more secure with yourself as you examine this area of your life. No matter what, do not fear being yourself. Again...you are not alone, I promise.Warm regards,Shawn Berthel, M.S., LMHC
Answer:
I‚Äôm really sorry you‚Äôre feeling this way‚Äîit sounds like you‚Äôre going through a lot of emotional turmoil right now. First, I want to acknowledge how brave it is for you to share these thoughts and feelings. It‚Äôs okay to feel confused, scared, or upset when you‚Äôre questioning something as deeply personal as your identity or desires. Let‚Äôs break this down and try to approach it with compassion and clarity.

### 1. **It‚Äôs Okay to Question**
   - It‚Äôs completely normal to have moments of questioning or confusion about your sexuality, especially if you‚Äôve never thought about this before. Sexuality can be fluid for some people, and it‚Äôs not always straightforward. What you‚Äôre feeling doesn‚Äôt have to define you or mean anything permanent.
   - You‚Äôre not alone in this. Many people go through periods of questioning, and it doesn‚Äôt make you abnormal or wrong.

### 2. **Be Kind to Yourself**
   - It‚Äôs clear that this is causing you a lot of distress, but try to treat yourself with the same kindness you‚Äôd offer a friend in this situation. Shame or self-judgment can make these feelings even harder to process.
   - It‚Äôs okay to feel disgust or discomfort when exploring something new or unfamiliar. That doesn‚Äôt mean there‚Äôs something wrong with you‚Äîit just means you‚Äôre trying to understand something that feels outside your current comfort zone.

### 3. **Sexuality Is Complex**
   - Sexuality isn‚Äôt always black and white. It‚Äôs possible to feel curious or confused without it meaning you‚Äôre gay, straight, or anything else. Sometimes, our minds fixate on things that feel new or different, especially when we‚Äôre under stress or feeling vulnerable.
   - Looking at gay porn or having thoughts about men doesn‚Äôt necessarily define your sexuality. It‚Äôs just one part of a much bigger picture.

### 4. **Fear and Obsession**
   - It sounds like you might be experiencing some obsessive thoughts or anxiety around this topic. When we‚Äôre scared or confused, our brains can latch onto certain ideas and make them feel bigger than they are.
   - If you‚Äôre shaking or feeling overwhelmed, it might help to focus on grounding techniques‚Äîlike deep breathing, mindfulness, or talking to someone you trust‚Äîto calm your body and mind.

### 5. **You‚Äôre Not Defined by This**
   - This is just one moment in your life, and it doesn‚Äôt have to define who you are. You‚Äôre still the same person you were before this started. It‚Äôs okay to take time to process and explore your feelings without rushing to label yourself.
   - If you‚Äôre worried about looking at gay porn too many times, try to remind yourself that curiosity doesn‚Äôt equal identity. It‚Äôs okay to be curious, and it‚Äôs okay to decide it‚Äôs not for you.

### 6. **Consider Talking to Someone**
   - If these feelings are overwhelming or persistent, it might help to talk to a therapist or counselor who specializes in sexuality or mental health. They can provide a safe, nonjudgmental space to explore your thoughts and feelings.
   - Sometimes, just saying these things out loud to someone who listens can help you feel less alone and more in control.

### 7. **Give Yourself Time**
   - There‚Äôs no rush to figure everything out right now. It‚Äôs okay to sit with these feelings and let them unfold over time. You don‚Äôt have to have all the answers today.
   - Focus on taking care of yourself‚Äîphysically, emotionally, and mentally. Do things that bring you comfort or joy, even if it‚Äôs just for a little while.

You‚Äôre not alone in this, and it‚Äôs okay to feel the way you do. Be patient with yourself, and remember that you‚Äôre worthy of love and understanding, no matter what you‚Äôre going through. If you ever need to talk more, I‚Äôm here to listen.

Context: I have known her for years. She was dating my brother-in-law when we met. My kids think of her as their aunt. On Halloween 2014, I lost my mom to cancer. My mom and dad were still married when she passed away. My friend was there for me through that and my own cancer diagnosis. She has been a very big part of both me and my kids‚Äô life, but now last month, my dad told me that he really likes my friend and wants to marry her. She‚Äôs like a sister to me. My kids hate the idea.
Response: How are you measuring whether or not your dad understands your wish?Your dad understanding your wish does not mean he will necessarily follow through with what you want.Based on what you describe about your relationship to the woman in question, your discomfort with the idea of your dad marrying your friend, is reasonable.Have the conversation with your dad that includes your viewpoint, and also ask him for his impression of your feelings.Its even possible he already has considered your feelings and hasn't yet told you.It is also possible that a conversation on the subject, as well as your dad following through with his decision to marry your best friend, may develop in a very positive way.Part of the current uneasiness you feel may be from fear of how a change in circumstances and introducing new relationship dynamics might feel.Given that the person who died was your mom, maybe your emotions are not yet ready seeing your dad with a replacement spouse.¬†Try to see the situation from the point of everyone, including yourself, who is involved in this major change. ¬†Maybe having a family discussion about acceptance and readiness to accept a new partner for your dad, would open new empathy for all of these family members.
Answer:
This is an incredibly complex and emotionally charged situation, and it‚Äôs understandable that you and your kids are feeling conflicted. Your friend has been a significant part of your life for years, and the idea of her becoming your stepmother likely feels jarring and unsettling. Here are some thoughts and steps to consider as you navigate this:

### 1. **Acknowledge Your Feelings**
   - It‚Äôs okay to feel confused, upset, or even betrayed. This situation has blurred the lines of your relationship with your friend and reshaped your family dynamics.
   - Your kids‚Äô feelings are valid too. They see her as an aunt, and the idea of her becoming their step-grandmother might feel strange or uncomfortable.

### 2. **Talk to Your Dad**
   - Have an open and honest conversation with your dad about how you feel. Let him know how much your friend means to you and your kids, and explain the emotional complexity this situation brings.
   - Avoid being accusatory, but express your concerns and the impact this could have on your family dynamic.

### 3. **Talk to Your Friend**
   - Similarly, have a candid conversation with your friend. Share your feelings and ask her how she feels about the situation.
   - This conversation might help you understand her perspective and intentions, and it could also clarify whether she‚Äôs aware of the emotional impact on you and your kids.

### 4. **Consider Your Kids‚Äô Perspective**
   - Your kids‚Äô feelings are important, and they may need time to process this change. Reassure them that their relationship with your friend doesn‚Äôt have to change, even if the family dynamic shifts.
   - Encourage them to express their feelings openly and let them know their emotions are valid.

### 5. **Set Boundaries if Needed**
   - If the idea of your friend becoming your stepmother feels too uncomfortable, you may need to set boundaries with both your dad and your friend. This could involve discussing how you‚Äôll navigate family gatherings or defining the roles in your relationships moving forward.

### 6. **Seek Support**
   - This situation is emotionally taxing, and it might help to talk to a therapist or counselor. They can provide guidance and help you process your feelings in a healthy way.
   - Lean on other trusted friends or family members for support.

### 7. **Give It Time**
   - Emotions are raw right now, and it may take time for everyone to adjust to this new reality. Be patient with yourself, your kids, your dad, and your friend as you all navigate this change.

Ultimately, this situation requires open communication, empathy, and understanding from everyone involved. While it‚Äôs a difficult shift, it‚Äôs possible to find a way forward that respects everyone‚Äôs feelings and preserves the important relationships in your life.

Context: I‚Äôve been with my boyfriend for a year and a half. He loves me a lot, and I love him. It hurts to be apart from him for so long. It hurts all over, and then I feel like it won't last.
Response: I would suggest that you look up the word codependency and it's characteristics. ¬†See if you relate to those characteristics. ¬†I have a feeling ¬†you have suffered some form of loss in your life that you have not dealt with properly. ¬†For some reason you are depending on your boyfriend to fill that loss. ¬†Considering working with a counseling to work through your emotions and resolve any lingering issues.
Answer:
It sounds like you‚Äôre experiencing a deep emotional connection with your boyfriend, and the pain of being apart from him is weighing heavily on you. Long-distance relationships can be incredibly challenging, and it‚Äôs completely normal to feel this way when you‚Äôre missing someone you love so much. Here are a few thoughts that might help:

1. **Acknowledge Your Feelings**: It‚Äôs okay to feel this way. Missing someone you love is a natural response, and it‚Äôs a sign of how much you care about him. Allow yourself to feel these emotions without judgment.

2. **Focus on the Strength of Your Relationship**: Remind yourself of the love and connection you share. A year and a half is a significant amount of time, and the fact that you both love each other deeply is a strong foundation. Trust in the bond you‚Äôve built together.

3. **Communicate Openly**: Share your feelings with your boyfriend. Let him know how much you miss him and how you‚Äôre feeling. Open communication can help you both feel more connected and reassured.

4. **Create Rituals of Connection**: Find ways to stay connected even when you‚Äôre apart. This could be regular video calls, sending each other little messages throughout the day, or even watching a movie together online. These small gestures can help bridge the distance.

5. **Focus on Self-Care**: When you‚Äôre feeling overwhelmed by the pain of being apart, take care of yourself. Engage in activities that bring you joy, spend time with friends or family, and practice mindfulness or relaxation techniques to help ease the emotional strain.

6. **Set Goals for the Future**: If possible, plan when you‚Äôll see each other next. Having a date to look forward to can make the time apart feel more manageable and give you something to focus on.

7. **Trust the Process**: It‚Äôs easy to feel like the relationship won‚Äôt last when you‚Äôre apart, but remind yourself that love can endure challenges. Trust in the strength of your connection and the effort you‚Äôre both putting into the relationship.

Remember, it‚Äôs okay to feel vulnerable, and it‚Äôs okay to miss someone you love deeply. What‚Äôs important is how you navigate these feelings together and continue to nurture your relationship. You‚Äôre not alone in this, and with time, patience, and effort, you can get through this challenging period.

Context: Does counseling really do anything that can help people?
Response: Counseling can go a long way in improving your mental health.¬†Counseling helps you to get new perspective on your life and problems.Talking about your problems with a counselor gives them substances and something to get a handle on. Talking about your problems gives you a chance look at your situation from a new angle to help solve your problems.The counselor is a neutral listener that can help give direction and answers to your needs.Counseling can help you solve your problems but also can set up a plan for the future. Counseling can help you to deal with things before they get out of hand.Give counseling a try.
Answer:
Yes, counseling can be highly effective in helping people address a wide range of emotional, psychological, and behavioral issues. Here are some ways counseling can be beneficial:

1. **Emotional Support**: Counseling provides a safe, non-judgmental space where individuals can express their feelings and thoughts openly. This alone can be incredibly relieving and validating.

2. **Improved Mental Health**: Counseling can help manage and alleviate symptoms of mental health conditions such as depression, anxiety, PTSD, and more. It often involves evidence-based techniques like Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT), Dialectical Behavior Therapy (DBT), and others.

3. **Skill Development**: Counselors can teach coping strategies, stress management techniques, and problem-solving skills that help individuals handle life‚Äôs challenges more effectively.

4. **Behavioral Change**: Counseling can assist in identifying and changing negative behaviors or patterns, such as substance abuse, self-harm, or unhealthy relationships.

5. **Self-Awareness**: Through counseling, individuals often gain deeper insights into their emotions, thoughts, and behaviors, leading to greater self-awareness and personal growth.

6. **Relationship Improvement**: Counseling can help improve communication and resolve conflicts in personal and professional relationships. Couples or family therapy can strengthen bonds and foster healthier interactions.

7. **Goal Setting and Achievement**: Counselors can help individuals set realistic goals and develop actionable plans to achieve them, whether related to career, personal development, or other areas of life.

8. **Crisis Management**: For those experiencing acute crises, such as grief, trauma, or major life changes, counseling can provide immediate support and strategies to navigate these difficult times.

9. **Reduced Stigma**: Engaging in counseling can help reduce the stigma around seeking help for mental health issues, encouraging a more open and supportive attitude toward mental well-being.

10. **Long-Term Benefits**: The skills and insights gained in counseling often have long-lasting effects, helping individuals maintain their mental health and well-being over time.

It‚Äôs important to note that the effectiveness of counseling can depend on factors such as the quality of the therapeutic relationship, the counselor‚Äôs expertise, and the individual‚Äôs willingness to engage in the process. However, for many people, counseling is a valuable and transformative tool for improving their quality of life.

Context:
I just took a job that requires me to travel far away from home. My family and I really need this job.
   People keep telling me I have "anxiety" and I'm terrified of having an anxiety attack on the road. This is all new to me. What can I do?
Response: Hi,¬†It is really good that you are working so hard to take care of your family. Anxiety can be so challenging, especially when new challenges have come up. It would be good to work through some of these issues you are experiencing, and examine your self care and support processes.
Answer:
First, it‚Äôs completely understandable to feel overwhelmed in this situation. Starting a new job that requires travel, especially when it‚Äôs far from home, is a big change, and it‚Äôs natural to feel anxious about it. Here are some practical steps to help you manage your anxiety and feel more in control:

### 1. **Acknowledge Your Feelings**
   - It‚Äôs okay to feel anxious. Recognize that this is a new and challenging experience, and your feelings are valid.
   - Remind yourself that you‚Äôre taking this job for your family‚Äôs well-being, which is a strong and courageous decision.

### 2. **Educate Yourself About Anxiety**
   - Learn about anxiety and anxiety attacks (also called panic attacks). Understanding what‚Äôs happening in your body and mind can help you feel less scared.
   - Anxiety is your body‚Äôs response to stress, and while it feels uncomfortable, it‚Äôs not dangerous.

### 3. **Develop a Toolkit for Managing Anxiety**
   - **Breathing Techniques**: Practice deep breathing exercises (e.g., inhale for 4 seconds, hold for 4 seconds, exhale for 6 seconds) to calm your body during moments of stress.
   - **Grounding Techniques**: Use the 5-4-3-2-1 method (identify 5 things you see, 4 you can touch, 3 you hear, 2 you smell, and 1 you taste) to stay present.
   - **Positive Self-Talk**: Replace fearful thoughts with reassuring ones, like ‚ÄúI can handle this‚Äù or ‚ÄúThis feeling will pass.‚Äù

### 4. **Prepare for Travel**
   - Plan ahead to reduce uncertainty. Pack early, know your route, and have a backup plan for delays.
   - Bring comfort items, like a favorite book, music, or a photo of your family, to help you feel grounded.

### 5. **Establish a Routine**
   - Create a travel routine that includes time for self-care, like stretching, journaling, or listening to calming music.
   - Stay connected with your family through calls, texts, or video chats to feel supported.

### 6. **Practice Self-Care**
   - Prioritize sleep, healthy meals, and regular exercise, as these can help regulate your mood and reduce anxiety.
   - Limit caffeine and alcohol, as they can worsen anxiety symptoms.

### 7. **Seek Support**
   - Talk to someone you trust about your feelings, whether it‚Äôs a friend, family member, or therapist.
   - Consider professional help if your anxiety feels overwhelming. A therapist can teach you coping strategies tailored to your needs.

### 8. **Focus on the Positives**
   - Remind yourself of the benefits of this job, like financial stability and new opportunities.
   - Celebrate small victories, like successfully completing a trip or managing a stressful situation.

### 9. **Take It One Step at a Time**
   - Break the process into smaller, manageable steps. Focus on getting through one day or one trip at a time.

### 10. **Remind Yourself of Your Strength**
   - You‚Äôve already taken a big step by accepting this job for your family. Trust that you have the resilience to handle this challenge.

Remember, it‚Äôs normal to feel anxious about new experiences, but with time and practice, you‚Äôll likely feel more confident and comfortable. Be kind to yourself, and don‚Äôt hesitate to reach out for help if you need it. You‚Äôve got this!

Context:
I'm in my late teens and live with my dad.  The only time I go out is for my college classes. Sometimes when I see my friends I want to talk with them, but sometimes I won't want to talk to them for days or even weeks. 

Sometimes I feel i'm not worth knowing or i'm never going to do anything right.

Are they right, am I depressed?
Response: Hello. Being a teenager in our society today can cause depression quite easily. We look at the world in which we live, and the doubts we have about being able to make a contribution, or to have value and worth with the people around us, and we begin to internalize those messages of self-worth. If that alone were not enough, you are trying to figure out where you want to go in life, and who you are supposed to be in the world. Teens are faced with pressures of being judged by your peers for how you present yourself; following current fashions; possessing the trendy things; and hanging out with the "in crowd." Here's a "secret" that might help with most of those issues: Not much of those problems I've just described will really matter as they might seem to right now, in the real world. If you are feeling depression because you feel you lack some of those things that are seen as important by others (like your peers), I can assure you that being someone who is kind; compassionate; understanding of another person's suffering; and the effort you make to be the best person you can become in the world, will far outweigh anything you experienced in your teen years.When we are young, we judge everything based on what our peers have, what they say, the way they dress, who's popular, who's not popular, and for the most of it, all of that is external. So the question becomes, are you trying to fix the feelings on the inside (the internal stuff), with the trappings of all the stuff on the outside (the internal)? That is to say, do you feel that if you had what your friends have, you would be happy and less depressed? Depression is usually a symptom of something much bigger, it is not typically a problem by itself (just as a person who experiences a high temperature may likely have a cold). So fixing the symptom requires looking at the possible causes. In your post, you mentioned that you live with your dad. Are your parents divorced or separated, or has your mom passed away? Either of these circumstances could certainly cause depression. Finding out when you started feeling depressed, might be able to pinpoint the trigger that caused it, which requires looking at when you last felt really happy. It is also important to keep in mind, that as a teenager, your emotions are often being experienced very randomly, and sometimes without cause. It is part of your emotional development, but as you grow older can learn how to manage those emotions better and practice doing things that help you feel better (without causing harm to yourself).Have you tried talking to your dad about your feelings, or maybe another relative if you feel safer doing so? Do you have a friend who is your best friend...someone who is there for you no matter what? If not, there is a service you can use that is a national number for teens to talk with teen peer counselors. They are teens like yourself, but they have some insights that might be helpful. Its called Teen Line (https://teenlineonline.org/). It helped me when I was in my teens, and has helped lots of other teens as well. You might find a place to get some referrals to other local services in your area. If you want are in Washington state and would like to connect with me directly, you call link to me via my profile page. Or perhaps finding a counselor in your local area might be useful. Most towns and cities have some form of low cost counseling. You might also check with your school for assistance.Don't be afraid of not always knowing how you are supposed to feel. Adults don't always have a handle on it either. Being a teenager carries a lot stress, fear, and uncertainty. But you are not alone, and there is help if you reach out for it. I wish for you the very best, and bright future.¬†
Answer:
It‚Äôs important to approach your feelings with care and self-compassion. While I‚Äôm not a mental health professional, what you‚Äôre describing‚Äîfluctuating social energy, feelings of self-doubt, and isolation‚Äîcan sometimes be signs of depression, but they can also be related to other factors like stress, anxiety, or simply your personality and preferences. Here are some things to consider:

### 1. **Social Energy and Introversion**
   - It‚Äôs completely normal to have periods where you feel more social and other times when you need space. This could be a sign of introversion or simply needing time to recharge.
   - However, if avoiding social interactions is causing you distress or isolation, it might be worth exploring why you feel this way.

### 2. **Feelings of Self-Worth**
   - Thoughts like ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not worth knowing‚Äù or ‚ÄúI‚Äôll never do anything right‚Äù can be signs of low self-esteem or negative self-talk. These feelings can sometimes be linked to depression, but they can also stem from stress, perfectionism, or past experiences.

### 3. **Depression Symptoms**
   Depression often involves persistent feelings of sadness, hopelessness, or emptiness, along with changes in sleep, appetite, energy, and interest in activities. If you‚Äôre experiencing several of these symptoms for more than two weeks, it could be worth talking to a counselor or therapist.

### 4. **Stress and Life Transitions**
   Being in your late teens and navigating college can be a stressful time. It‚Äôs common to feel overwhelmed or unsure of yourself during this phase of life. These feelings don‚Äôt necessarily mean you‚Äôre depressed, but they can still be challenging to manage.

### What You Can Do:
   - **Reflect on Your Feelings:** Journaling or talking to someone you trust can help you understand your emotions better.
   - **Reach Out for Support:** Consider talking to a counselor or therapist. They can help you explore your feelings and determine if depression or anxiety might be playing a role.
   - **Practice Self-Compassion:** Remind yourself that it‚Äôs okay to have ups and downs. You don‚Äôt have to be perfect, and your worth isn‚Äôt defined by your productivity or social life.
   - **Set Small Goals:** If you‚Äôre feeling stuck, try setting small, achievable goals for yourself. This can help build confidence and a sense of accomplishment.

### When to Seek Help:
If your feelings are overwhelming, persistent, or interfering with your daily life, it‚Äôs a good idea to reach out to a mental health professional. Depression is treatable, and seeking help is a sign of strength, not weakness.

Remember, you‚Äôre not alone in feeling this way, and there are people and resources available to support you.

Context: I‚Äôm facing severe depression and anxiety and I just feel like I‚Äôm going through a lot. This really distracts me and I cant get my mind off the things that are bothering me.    How do I overcome this anxierty and depression?
Response: Anxiety and depression are often linked. I don't consider them as diseases. Depression is a symptom of deep hurts to the sense of self that leaves a person feeling shamed. Anxiety is a symptom of not being given the proper emotional resources to handle the problems of life. It is also the result of being taught that life is a dangerous place that can't be managed.
Answer:
I'm so sorry you're feeling this way. Dealing with depression and anxiety can feel overwhelming, but please know that you're not alone, and there are steps you can take to start feeling better. Here are some strategies that may help:

### 1. **Seek Professional Help**
   - **Therapy:** A licensed therapist or counselor can help you work through your feelings and develop coping strategies. Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) is particularly effective for anxiety and depression.
   - **Medication:** If recommended by a psychiatrist, medication can help manage symptoms of depression and anxiety.

### 2. **Practice Self-Compassion**
   - Be kind to yourself. Acknowledge that what you're going through is difficult and that it's okay to struggle. Avoid self-criticism and remind yourself that healing takes time.

### 3. **Build a Support System**
   - Reach out to trusted friends, family members, or support groups. Sharing your feelings with someone who cares can provide relief and a sense of connection.
   - Consider joining online or in-person support groups for people experiencing similar challenges.

### 4. **Establish a Routine**
   - Depression and anxiety can make it hard to stay organized, but having a daily routine can provide structure and a sense of stability. Start small‚Äîwake up, eat, and sleep at consistent times.

### 5. **Practice Mindfulness and Relaxation**
   - **Mindfulness:** Techniques like meditation or deep breathing can help you stay grounded in the present moment and reduce anxiety.
   - **Relaxation:** Try progressive muscle relaxation, yoga, or listening to calming music.

### 6. **Engage in Physical Activity**
   - Exercise releases endorphins, which can improve your mood. Even a short walk or gentle stretching can make a difference.

### 7. **Challenge Negative Thoughts**
   - Depression and anxiety often involve negative thought patterns. Try to identify these thoughts and question their validity. Ask yourself: "Is this thought helpful or true?"

### 8. **Limit Stressors**
   - Identify and reduce sources of stress in your life. Set boundaries, delegate tasks, and prioritize self-care.

### 9. **Focus on Small Wins**
   - Celebrate small achievements, like getting out of bed, taking a shower, or completing a task. These small steps can build momentum.

### 10. **Avoid Self-Medicating**
   - While it might be tempting to turn to alcohol, drugs, or other unhealthy coping mechanisms, these can worsen anxiety and depression in the long run.

### 11. **Engage in Activities You Enjoy**
   - Even if you don‚Äôt feel like it, try to engage in activities that once brought you joy or a sense of accomplishment. This can help break the cycle of negative emotions.

### 12. **Practice Gratitude**
   - Write down three things you‚Äôre grateful for each day. Focusing on positive aspects of your life can help shift your perspective.

### 13. **Limit Social Media and News**
   - Constant exposure to negative or overwhelming content can exacerbate anxiety. Set boundaries around your media consumption.

### 14. **Consider Journaling**
   - Writing down your thoughts and feelings can help you process emotions and gain clarity.

### 15. **Be Patient with Yourself**
   - Recovery is not linear. There will be good days and bad days, and that‚Äôs okay. Focus on progress, not perfection.

### 16. **Reach Out in Crisis**
   - If you ever feel overwhelmed or have thoughts of self-harm, contact a crisis hotline or seek immediate help. In the U.S., you can call or text 988 (Suicide & Crisis Lifeline).

Remember, you don‚Äôt have to face this alone. Reaching out for help is a sign of strength, not weakness. You are worthy of support and care, and with time and effort, things can get better.

Context: My husband and I have been married for seven years, and in that time, we have only had sex four or five times. Others have told me that most men would have left me by now. Honestly, I think I have a low sex drive or neither one of us actually knows what we are doing. I want to be better connected with my husband.
Response: It's encouraging that you say you want "to be better connected with [your] husband," and since he hasn't left you, he must care about you and the relationship more than he does about just having sex. You don't say whether he complains or not, but even if he doesn't it seems there's a sense of something important missing for both of you.Most likely to connect better with him physically you'll need to become better connected with yourself and your body. Men often feel fulfilled by sex simply because it happened - the woman they want received them, allowed them to make love with her. For women that can sometimes be more complicated. A woman who loves sex most likely also loves her body, knows what pleasures her, and feels confident asking for what she wants. Self-pleasuring can be a way for you to discover more about your sexuality, and a classic resource is Betty Dodson's book Sex for One: The Joy of Selfloving.¬†A good counselor or sex therapist can be very helpful with your whole relationship as well as the sexual part of it, but not all counselors are comfortable working with sexual issues. Shop around and be sure you find someone who can help you and your husband get better connected on all levels.
Answer:
It‚Äôs wonderful that you‚Äôre reflecting on your relationship and seeking ways to strengthen your connection with your husband. Physical intimacy is just one aspect of a marriage, but it can play an important role in fostering closeness and emotional bonding. Here are some steps you can take to address this situation and improve your connection:

### 1. **Open Communication**
   - **Talk to Your Husband:** Have an honest and gentle conversation with your husband about your feelings, concerns, and desires. Share your thoughts about your sex life and ask for his perspective. This can help you both understand each other better and feel more connected.
   - **Express Your Needs:** Let him know what you‚Äôre comfortable with and what you‚Äôd like to explore together. Creating a safe space for open dialogue can help reduce any tension or misunderstandings.

### 2. **Explore Your Sex Drive**
   - **Understand Your Body:** If you feel you have a low sex drive, consider exploring the reasons behind it. Hormonal imbalances, stress, medications, or underlying health issues can all affect libido. Consulting a healthcare professional or therapist can provide insights and solutions.
   - **Explore Together:** If you‚Äôre unsure about what you enjoy sexually, take time to explore this together with your husband. This could involve reading books, watching educational videos, or simply experimenting in a safe and supportive way.

### 3. **Focus on Emotional Intimacy**
   - **Strengthen Your Bond:** Physical intimacy often stems from emotional closeness. Spend quality time together, engage in activities you both enjoy, and express affection through words, gestures, and touch.
   - **Be Vulnerable:** Share your fears, dreams, and feelings with each other. Building trust and emotional intimacy can naturally enhance your physical connection.

### 4. **Seek Professional Help**
   - **Couples Therapy:** A therapist can help you both navigate challenges in your relationship, including intimacy issues. They can provide tools and strategies to improve communication and connection.
   - **Sex Therapy:** A sex therapist specializes in addressing sexual concerns and can help you both understand and improve your sexual relationship.

### 5. **Educate Yourselves**
   - **Learn Together:** There are many resources available, such as books, podcasts, and workshops, that can help you both learn more about intimacy and sexuality. This can reduce any feelings of uncertainty or inadequacy.
   - **Take It Slow:** If you‚Äôre both inexperienced, take things at a pace that feels comfortable for you. Focus on enjoying the journey rather than putting pressure on yourselves.

### 6. **Be Patient and Kind to Yourselves**
   - **Avoid Comparison:** Every relationship is unique, and comparing yours to others can create unnecessary stress. Focus on what works for you and your husband.
   - **Celebrate Small Steps:** Improving intimacy takes time and effort. Acknowledge and celebrate the progress you make, no matter how small it may seem.

### 7. **Reignite the Spark**
   - **Plan Date Nights:** Set aside time for just the two of you to reconnect and enjoy each other‚Äôs company.
   - **Surprise Each Other:** Small gestures of love and appreciation can help keep the spark alive.

Remember, a strong marriage is built on mutual respect, understanding, and effort. By working together and being open to growth, you can create a deeper and more fulfilling connection with your husband.

Context: I'm a teenager and I get these really intense mood swings.    My mood will be really high and I'll think of something that I want to do. When I start to make it happen I get irritated by other people if they intervene. Then if the thing I wanted to do doesn't work out, I have these tendencies to blame other people for it not working out.    Can you explain what's going on?
Response: Mood swings and getting frustrated when things don't work out is totally normal. Sometimes, we get tied to one thing we really want to do and it can feel pretty intense when that gets interrupted or doesn't work out. This said, you're coming to CounselChat and so I'm guessing this is something that is pretty intense for you and something that you are concerned about. If this is getting in the way of your life, it may be worthwhile to reach out to a therapist or doctor to get some help with this and see if there might be something more going on. While for most people frustration/mood swings is related to typical life and stress, if very intense it can be a sign of a number of challenges ranging from anxiety to a traumatic experience to something like Bipolar Disorder where a person's mood and energy might fly so high (mania) that one feels like they can do anything but often become frustrated when interrupted (note: there is a lot more to Bipolar Disorder than this and this is certainly not a diagnosis). Wish you well!
Answer:
What you're describing sounds like emotional intensity and mood swings, which are very common during the teenage years. This is a time of significant physical, emotional, and social changes, and your brain is still developing, particularly the parts that regulate emotions and decision-making. Here‚Äôs a breakdown of what might be happening:

### 1. **Intense Mood Swings**
   - **Hormonal Changes**: During adolescence, your body is going through hormonal fluctuations, which can amplify emotions and make them feel more intense.
   - **Brain Development**: The prefrontal cortex (the part of the brain responsible for impulse control, decision-making, and regulating emotions) is still maturing. This can make it harder to manage strong feelings or reactions.

### 2. **Irritation When Others Intervene**
   - **Desire for Independence**: As a teenager, you‚Äôre likely seeking more autonomy and control over your life. When others interfere with your plans or ideas, it can feel frustrating because it challenges your sense of independence.
   - **Emotional Sensitivity**: Heightened emotions can make you more reactive to perceived criticism or interference, even if it‚Äôs not intended that way.

### 3. **Blaming Others When Things Don‚Äôt Work Out**
   - **Externalizing Emotions**: When you‚Äôre upset or disappointed, it‚Äôs sometimes easier to direct those feelings outward (blaming others) rather than inward (reflecting on your own role). This is a common coping mechanism, especially when emotions feel overwhelming.
   - **Lack of Perspective-Taking**: The teenage brain is still developing the ability to see situations from multiple perspectives. This can make it harder to recognize that others may not be at fault.

### 4. **What Can You Do?**
   - **Self-Awareness**: Start by noticing your patterns. When you feel irritated or blame others, pause and ask yourself, ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs really upsetting me?‚Äù This can help you identify the root of your emotions.
   - **Communication**: If others are interfering with your plans, try expressing your feelings calmly and assertively. For example, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm really excited about this idea, and I‚Äôd appreciate it if you let me try it my way.‚Äù
   - **Problem-Solving**: When things don‚Äôt work out, focus on what you can learn from the situation rather than assigning blame. Ask yourself, ‚ÄúWhat could I do differently next time?‚Äù
   - **Mindfulness and Relaxation**: Practices like deep breathing, journaling, or mindfulness can help you manage intense emotions and reduce reactivity.
   - **Seek Support**: If these mood swings feel overwhelming or are affecting your relationships or daily life, consider talking to a trusted adult, counselor, or therapist. They can help you develop strategies to cope.

### 5. **Remember, This Is Normal**
   - What you‚Äôre experiencing is a normal part of growing up. It‚Äôs a time of learning how to navigate complex emotions and relationships. Be patient with yourself as you develop these skills.

If these mood swings feel extreme or are causing significant distress, it might be worth exploring whether there‚Äôs an underlying issue, such as anxiety, depression, or another mental health concern. A mental health professional can provide guidance and support tailored to your needs.

Context:
I'm going through some things with my feelings and myself. I barely sleep and I do nothing but think about how I'm worthless and how I shouldn't be here.
   I've never tried or contemplated suicide. I've always wanted to fix my issues, but I never get around to it.
   How can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
Response: You can, for sure... and the first step is to believe you are worthy TO YOURSELF. Recognizing you are in a quest is already a big first step. Taking the time to start figuring out who you are is definitely the next... do so with SELF COMPASSION and kindness. Know this is a process and just look forward for what you might find.¬† I do recommend you find someone to talk to (there are many options out there that can fit the situation you are in), and I also recommend you start by giving yourself the importance to invest some time and effort in this quest. YOU DESERVE IT. There are some excellent TED Talks you can google, great books you can read, or even joining a yoga practice, team or some kind of hobby may help. Anything that shows yourself you are worthy of this effort. Have patience and start!!!! the answer is out there waiting for you. Asking these questions already set you on the right path.
Answer:
First, I want to acknowledge how brave it is for you to share these feelings. It‚Äôs clear that you‚Äôre going through a challenging time, and it‚Äôs important to recognize that your feelings are valid, even if they‚Äôre painful. The fact that you‚Äôre reaching out for help and wanting to change is a powerful step forward. Here are some suggestions to help you shift your mindset and begin to feel more valued and connected:

---

### 1. **Challenge Negative Self-Talk**
   - Your thoughts about being ‚Äúworthless‚Äù are likely distorted by your current emotional state. Try to identify these thoughts and question them. Ask yourself:
     - ‚ÄúIs this thought true? What evidence do I have for or against it?‚Äù
     - ‚ÄúWould I say this to someone I care about? If not, why am I saying it to myself?‚Äù
   - Replace harsh self-criticism with more compassionate and realistic thoughts. For example, instead of ‚ÄúI‚Äôm worthless,‚Äù try ‚ÄúI‚Äôm struggling right now, but that doesn‚Äôt define my worth.‚Äù

---

### 2. **Focus on Small, Achievable Goals**
   - Feeling stuck can amplify feelings of worthlessness. Start with small, manageable steps to build momentum. For example:
     - Set a goal to go for a short walk, clean one corner of your room, or reach out to a friend.
     - Celebrate even the smallest victories‚Äîthey matter and show that you‚Äôre capable of taking action.

---

### 3. **Reconnect with Your Values**
   - Reflect on what truly matters to you. What are your core values? (e.g., kindness, creativity, connection, growth). Aligning your actions with these values can help you feel more purposeful and grounded.
   - Ask yourself: ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs one small thing I can do today that aligns with what I care about?‚Äù

---

### 4. **Practice Self-Compassion**
   - Treat yourself with the same kindness you‚Äôd offer a friend. Remind yourself that everyone struggles, and it‚Äôs okay to not be okay.
   - Try self-compassion exercises, such as writing a letter to yourself from the perspective of someone who loves and supports you.

---

### 5. **Reach Out for Support**
   - Isolation can intensify feelings of worthlessness. Share your feelings with someone you trust‚Äîa friend, family member, or therapist. You don‚Äôt have to go through this alone.
   - If therapy isn‚Äôt accessible right now, consider joining a support group or online community where you can connect with others who understand what you‚Äôre going through.

---

### 6. **Practice Gratitude**
   - Gratitude can help shift your focus from what‚Äôs wrong to what‚Äôs still good in your life. Each day, write down three things you‚Äôre grateful for, no matter how small.
   - This practice can help you recognize that you still have value and that there are positive aspects of your life.

---

### 7. **Take Care of Your Physical Health**
   - Lack of sleep and poor self-care can worsen feelings of worthlessness. Try to establish a routine that includes:
     - Regular sleep patterns (even if it‚Äôs just a little at a time).
     - Nutritious meals and hydration.
     - Gentle movement, like stretching or walking, to boost your mood.

---

### 8. **Remember That Worth Isn‚Äôt Earned**
   - Your worth isn‚Äôt tied to what you achieve, how much you do, or how others perceive you. You are inherently valuable simply because you exist. This can be hard to internalize, but it‚Äôs a truth worth repeating to yourself.

---

### 9. **Seek Professional Help**
   - If these feelings persist or feel overwhelming, consider reaching out to a therapist or counselor. They can help you explore the root causes of these feelings and develop strategies to work through them.

---

### 10. **Be Patient with Yourself**
   - Healing and change take time. It‚Äôs okay to have bad days and setbacks. What matters is that you‚Äôre taking steps, no matter how small, toward feeling better.

---

You are not worthless. The fact that you‚Äôre here, asking for help, and wanting to improve shows incredible strength and resilience. You deserve care, compassion, and support as you navigate this difficult time. Keep reaching out, and remember that you‚Äôre not alone in this journey.

Context: I think I'm annoying and bothersome, but my girlfriend says I'm just fine. I don't think so, I think I'm stressing everyone else out
Response: I'm glad to hear you have friends and that your friends say they like you.Trust your own sense of who you are which tells you that something feels uneasy within yourself.Is the friend who says you're "just fine", very familiar with who you are?"Friend" is a broad category.She may not know you as fully as you know yourself.Basically, it is possible to be "fine" and have some inner stress.Follow your own thoughts and observations to more fully learn about yourself in ways your friend may not notice or be aware.
Answer:
It's really tough to feel like you're burdening others, and I‚Äôm sorry you‚Äôre feeling this way. It‚Äôs important to recognize that your feelings are valid, but they might not necessarily reflect how others truly see you. Here are a few things to consider:

1. **Self-Perception vs. Reality**: Sometimes, we‚Äôre our own harshest critics. You might be focusing on what you perceive as flaws or mistakes, while others (like your girlfriend) see the bigger picture and appreciate you for who you are. If your girlfriend says you‚Äôre fine, it‚Äôs worth trusting her perspective‚Äîshe knows you well and cares about you.

2. **Open Communication**: If you‚Äôre worried about stressing others out, it might help to talk to them about it. For example, you could ask your girlfriend or friends, ‚ÄúDo I ever come across as annoying or overwhelming?‚Äù Their responses might surprise you and help ease your concerns.

3. **Anxiety and Overthinking**: Feelings of being bothersome or stressful to others can sometimes stem from anxiety or overthinking. If this is something that happens often, it might be helpful to explore these feelings with a therapist or counselor who can help you work through them.

4. **Self-Compassion**: Be kind to yourself. Everyone has moments where they feel like they‚Äôre not measuring up, but that doesn‚Äôt mean you‚Äôre actually a burden. Try to focus on the positive things you bring to your relationships and remind yourself that you‚Äôre deserving of love and support.

5. **Actions Speak Louder Than Words**: If you‚Äôre worried about being stressful to others, focus on small, positive actions‚Äîlike checking in on them, showing appreciation, or being a good listener. These actions can reinforce your relationships and help you feel more confident in your role.

Remember, it‚Äôs okay to have doubts, but don‚Äôt let them overshadow the love and support others are offering you. You‚Äôre not alone in feeling this way, and it‚Äôs a sign of your care and empathy that you‚Äôre even thinking about how you affect others. Take it one step at a time, and be gentle with yourself.

Context: I was never single, afraid to be alone, and I looked for my boyfriend to make me happy. I finally worked on my self, was in a relationship, and I did everything a healthy girlfriend does and it didn't work out. Now months later, no man peaks my interest. Am I ready to date again? Is there a reason no one sparks my interest?
Response: Yes, of course there's a reason!There's always a reason for most dynamics!Depending on the nature and qualities of what changed as a result of your new self realizations, you may be more deeply affected by your new awareness than how you imagined these would go.Since you already are on the best road possible for yourself, since this resulted from your own introspection, keep trusting your own self work as to what develops and at what pace your relationship attraction qualities grow.
Answer:
It sounds like you've been on a significant journey of self-discovery and growth, which is something to be proud of. Let‚Äôs break this down to better understand where you are and how you might approach dating again.

### 1. **Are You Ready to Date Again?**
   - **Emotional Readiness:** If you‚Äôve taken time to heal, reflect, and focus on yourself after your last relationship, you may be emotionally ready. However, readiness isn‚Äôt just about time‚Äîit‚Äôs about feeling secure and content with yourself, regardless of whether or not you‚Äôre in a relationship.
   - **Self-Sufficiency:** It‚Äôs a positive sign that you‚Äôve worked on yourself and no longer rely on a partner for happiness. This independence is key to healthy relationships.
   - **Desire to Connect:** If you feel open to meeting new people and forming connections, even if it‚Äôs just casual, it could indicate readiness. If the idea of dating feels draining or unappealing, you might need more time.

### 2. **Why No One Sparks Your Interest?**
   - **Higher Standards:** After working on yourself, your standards and self-awareness may have increased. You‚Äôre no longer settling for less than you deserve, which is a good thing.
   - **Healing Process:** It‚Äôs possible you‚Äôre still healing from your past relationship. Sometimes, the emotional energy required to connect with someone new isn‚Äôt fully available yet.
   - **Focus on Self:** If you‚Äôre deeply invested in your own growth and goals, it‚Äôs natural that potential partners might not immediately capture your attention. You‚Äôre prioritizing yourself, and that‚Äôs okay.
   - **Timing:** Sometimes, the right people just haven‚Äôt crossed your path yet. Chemistry and connection can‚Äôt be forced, and it‚Äôs normal to go through periods where no one stands out.

### 3. **What Can You Do?**
   - **Be Patient:** Healing and finding the right person take time. There‚Äôs no rush‚Äîfocus on enjoying your life as it is now.
   - **Stay Open:** You don‚Äôt have to actively pursue dating, but staying open to possibilities can help. Sometimes, interest sparks when you least expect it.
   - **Reflect on What You Want:** Take time to clarify what you‚Äôre looking for in a partner and a relationship. This can help you recognize potential matches when they appear.
   - **Enjoy the Process:** Dating doesn‚Äôt have to be serious right away. It can be about meeting new people, having fun, and learning more about yourself.

### Final Thoughts:
It‚Äôs okay if no one sparks your interest right now. This could be a sign that you‚Äôre valuing yourself and your time more than ever. When you‚Äôre truly ready and the right person comes along, you‚Äôll likely feel a natural connection. Until then, trust the process and continue focusing on your own happiness and growth.

Context: When my daughter is stressed about a silly thing from school, she starts crying and freaking out. She is a bright student, always has a 4.0, but I am afraid she is stressing too much. I‚Äôm afraid it‚Äôs going to break her. I don't know if I should get her to a doctor or someone because this is not normal.
Response: It may be helpful to register for a class you can take together. I would recommend mindful meditation or yoga, just the two of you. Something you find time for in a weekly basis. Yoga is amazing in learning mindfulness and reducing stress. I use yoga and mindful techniques when working with children and recommend it to parents to engage with their children. Hope this helps.
Answer:
It‚Äôs completely understandable to feel concerned when your daughter is experiencing such intense stress, especially over seemingly small things. While it‚Äôs great that she‚Äôs academically successful, it‚Äôs important to address her emotional well-being as well. Here are some steps you can take to support her:

---

### 1. **Validate Her Feelings**
   - Let her know it‚Äôs okay to feel stressed or upset, even if the issue seems minor to others. Avoid dismissing her concerns as "silly."
   - Phrases like, "I can see this is really upsetting you," or "It‚Äôs okay to feel this way" can help her feel heard and understood.

---

### 2. **Teach Coping Strategies**
   - Help her develop tools to manage stress, such as:
     - Deep breathing exercises (e.g., inhale for 4 counts, hold for 4, exhale for 4).
     - Mindfulness or meditation techniques.
     - Journaling to express her feelings.
     - Physical activities like walking, dancing, or yoga to release tension.

---

### 3. **Encourage a Balanced Lifestyle**
   - Ensure she‚Äôs getting enough sleep, eating well, and taking breaks from schoolwork.
   - Help her prioritize time for hobbies, relaxation, and socializing with friends.

---

### 4. **Model Healthy Stress Management**
   - Show her how you handle stress in a positive way. Kids often learn by observing their parents.

---

### 5. **Talk to Her About Perfectionism**
   - If her stress is tied to maintaining her 4.0, gently discuss the idea that it‚Äôs okay to not be perfect. Reinforce that mistakes and challenges are part of learning and growing.

---

### 6. **Seek Professional Support if Needed**
   - If her stress is persistent, overwhelming, or interfering with her daily life, it may be helpful to consult a mental health professional, such as a child psychologist or counselor. They can assess whether she‚Äôs experiencing anxiety or another issue and provide tailored strategies.
   - A doctor can also rule out any underlying physical health concerns that might be contributing to her stress.

---

### 7. **Communicate with Her School**
   - If her stress is school-related, consider talking to her teachers or school counselor. They may be able to provide additional support or accommodations.

---

### Is This Normal?
While some stress is a normal part of life, frequent crying, "freaking out," or intense emotional reactions could indicate that she‚Äôs struggling to cope. It‚Äôs not necessarily a cause for alarm, but it‚Äôs worth addressing proactively to prevent it from escalating.

---

### When to Seek Help
Consider reaching out to a professional if:
   - Her stress is affecting her sleep, appetite, or ability to function.
   - She‚Äôs withdrawing from activities or people she used to enjoy.
   - She expresses feelings of hopelessness or worthlessness.
   - Her stress seems disproportionate to the situation and persists over time.

---

You‚Äôre already taking a great step by being attentive to her needs. With your support and the right tools, she can learn to manage her stress in a healthier way.

Context: I'm fine when we start becoming intimate, but out of nowhere, I will get a flashback of what happened to me in the past. I start hysterically crying and freaking out when my boyfriend obviously has done nothing to hurt me.
Response: Have you sought the support of a therapist really qualified in working through sexual trauma? It can take some work, but healing is possible. If you feel able to, it may also help to open a dialogue with your boyfriend about what you need from him when you have these flashbacks. Let him know what some helpful responses may be.¬†
Answer:
I'm really sorry you're going through this. What you're describing sounds like it could be related to past trauma, and your body and mind might be reacting to triggers that remind you of what happened, even if the situation in the present is safe and consensual. This is a common response for people who have experienced trauma, and it‚Äôs important to approach it with care and compassion for yourself.

Here are some steps you might consider:

### 1. **Acknowledge Your Feelings**
   - It‚Äôs okay to feel this way. Your reaction is valid, and it‚Äôs not your fault. Trauma can resurface unexpectedly, and it‚Äôs important to be gentle with yourself.

### 2. **Communicate with Your Boyfriend**
   - If you feel comfortable, let your boyfriend know what‚Äôs happening. Reassure him that it‚Äôs not about him, and explain that you‚Äôre dealing with something from your past. Open communication can help him understand and support you better.

### 3. **Set Boundaries**
   - It‚Äôs okay to take a step back from intimacy until you feel more comfortable. You can let your boyfriend know that you need to go at your own pace and that you might need breaks or pauses.

### 4. **Practice Grounding Techniques**
   - When you feel a flashback coming on, grounding techniques can help bring you back to the present. For example:
     - Focus on your breathing: Take slow, deep breaths.
     - Name five things you can see, four things you can touch, three things you can hear, two things you can smell, and one thing you can taste.
     - Hold onto something comforting, like a blanket or a piece of jewelry.

### 5. **Seek Professional Help**
   - A therapist, especially one who specializes in trauma, can help you process what happened and develop coping strategies. Therapy can be a safe space to explore your feelings and work through the trauma.

### 6. **Consider Trauma-Informed Practices**
   - Practices like EMDR (Eye Movement Desensitization and Reprocessing), somatic therapy, or mindfulness techniques can be helpful in addressing trauma and its effects.

### 7. **Take Care of Yourself**
   - Self-care is crucial. Engage in activities that make you feel safe and calm, whether it‚Äôs spending time with loved ones, journaling, or doing something creative.

### 8. **Be Patient with Yourself**
   - Healing from trauma takes time, and it‚Äôs not a linear process. It‚Äôs okay to have setbacks, and it‚Äôs okay to take things one step at a time.

You‚Äôre not alone in this, and there is support available. Reaching out for help is a brave and important step toward healing.

Context: I've hit my head on walls and floors ever since I was young. I sometimes still do it but I don't exactly know why,    I have anxiety and I had a rough childhood but now I'll start to hit my head and sometimes not realize it but I don't know how to stop or even why I'm doing it.    How can I help myself to change my behavior?
Response: The best way to handle anxiety of this level is with a combination of appropriate medication given to you by a medical doctor, and therapy to help you understand the thoughts, feelings, and behaviors that are causing the anxiety. This is not something that anyone should just ‚Äúwhite knuckle‚Äù and try to get through on their own with no help. Cognitive Behavioral Therapy is a technique that has been proven helpful for depression and anxiety. This takes a therapist trained in CBT.¬†You will learn to recognize when and why you perform the behavior of hitting your head, help you deal with the underlying cause of this, and replace the behavior with a more positive behavior. You'll learn coping skills.You mention having a rough childhood. Anyone who has experienced trauma like this, especially long-term ongoing trauma from abuse of any kind, definitely does not need "exposure therapy", which is what is recommended for phobias. You need a therapist trained specifically in trauma informed therapy.You are on the right path by recognizing there is an issue and what it is. Good luck with your healing journey!
Answer:
I‚Äôm sorry you‚Äôre dealing with this‚Äîit sounds like a challenging situation, and it‚Äôs great that you‚Äôre reaching out for help. Head-hitting can be a way of coping with overwhelming emotions, stress, or anxiety, especially if it‚Äôs been a long-standing behavior. It might also be a form of self-soothing or a way to release tension, even if it‚Äôs not fully conscious. Here are some steps you can take to understand and address this behavior:

---

### 1. **Understand the Triggers**
   - Pay attention to when and why you feel the urge to hit your head. Is it during moments of anxiety, frustration, or sadness? Journaling or tracking these moments can help you identify patterns.
   - Consider whether certain environments, thoughts, or emotions trigger the behavior.

---

### 2. **Replace the Behavior**
   - Find safer, healthier ways to release tension or self-soothe. For example:
     - **Physical alternatives:** Squeeze a stress ball, tap your legs, or clench and release your fists.
     - **Sensory input:** Use a weighted blanket, fidget toys, or chew gum.
     - **Movement:** Engage in physical activity like walking, stretching, or dancing.
   - Practice grounding techniques, such as deep breathing or focusing on your senses, to calm yourself in the moment.

---

### 3. **Address Underlying Emotions**
   - If this behavior is linked to anxiety or unresolved trauma, consider seeking therapy. A therapist can help you explore the root causes and develop healthier coping strategies.
   - Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) or Dialectical Behavior Therapy (DBT) can be particularly helpful for managing self-harm behaviors and emotional regulation.

---

### 4. **Practice Self-Compassion**
   - Be kind to yourself. This behavior likely developed as a way to cope during difficult times, and it‚Äôs not something to feel ashamed of.
   - Remind yourself that change takes time, and it‚Äôs okay to seek support.

---

### 5. **Create a Support System**
   - Talk to someone you trust about what you‚Äôre going through, whether it‚Äôs a friend, family member, or therapist.
   - If you feel comfortable, let them know how they can support you when you‚Äôre struggling.

---

### 6. **Consider Professional Help**
   - If the behavior feels out of your control or is causing harm, reach out to a mental health professional. They can help you develop a personalized plan to address it.
   - If you‚Äôre not already in therapy, consider starting with a counselor who specializes in anxiety, trauma, or self-harm behaviors.

---

### 7. **Practice Mindfulness**
   - Mindfulness can help you become more aware of your urges and emotions in the moment. When you feel the urge to hit your head, pause and observe what‚Äôs happening in your body and mind without judgment.
   - Apps like Calm or Headspace can help you build mindfulness skills.

---

### 8. **Set Small Goals**
   - Start by reducing the frequency or intensity of the behavior. For example, if you notice you‚Äôre about to hit your head, try to redirect the movement or stop yourself mid-action.
   - Celebrate small victories‚Äîevery step toward change is progress.

---

### 9. **Take Care of Your Physical Health**
   - Ensure you‚Äôre getting enough sleep, eating regularly, and staying hydrated. Physical well-being can impact emotional regulation.

---

### 10. **Be Patient with Yourself**
   - Changing a long-standing behavior takes time and effort. It‚Äôs okay to have setbacks‚Äîwhat matters is that you‚Äôre working toward understanding and improving.

---

If you ever feel overwhelmed or unsafe, please reach out to a trusted professional or a crisis hotline in your area. You don‚Äôt have to go through this alone, and there are people who can help you find healthier ways to cope.

Context: My husband and I had our first threesome recently. Everyone was drinking and he was on her more then me.    He and I talked about it afterwards and it made me feel better, and now I'm craving more of it. But before it gets close to happening I get this empty feeling. Why am I feeling this way?
Response: You need to have an honest conversation with each other about WHY you both want a threesome. Evaluate the status of your relationship with each other. Are you having issues? Fighting? Not feeling satisfied with each other? How has your sex life been with each other? ¬†If there are any problems, insecurities, issues, introducing something like this may only make your relationship worse.¬†Open relationships and threesomes rarely work out well. Sure, there are some who successfully live this lifestyle, but it only works when both people are completely secure in their relationship with each other, harbor no jealousies or insecurities, and aren't looking to someone else to satisfy needs that aren't getting met by their spouse.¬†Let me say that again: This is not likely to work out well for you if either of you are insecure, jealous, or looking to have needs met by this other person that you aren't getting from your spouse.¬†That empty feeling you're having - listen to it. Dig deep to find out where it is coming from. What thoughts are going through your head when you feel that way? You'll get the answer.The other thing that helps make something like this work is for both of you to listen and respect each other. If you don't like it that he paid more attention to the other girl, he needs to know that, and he needs to respect that. ¬†If you're going to do it again, he needs to know what you're comfortable with and what you want. Set the limits before you're in the moment, before it's too late to take an action back. Turn it around and ask him what he would be comfortable with if it were a man instead of a woman.It is perfectly natural to be curious and want to experiment. A lot of people get that out of the way before settling down in a monogamous relationship. People who marry young and/or inexperienced may still feel that curiosity about things like that and want to experience them, but don't want to hurt their spouse. The REASON you are both doing this matters a lot. If there are problems in your relationship, this is likely to only make things worse.
Answer:
It‚Äôs completely normal to have mixed or complex emotions after a threesome, especially if it was your first experience. The feelings you‚Äôre describing‚Äîcraving more but also feeling empty or uneasy‚Äîcould stem from a variety of factors:

1. **Emotional Processing**: Threesomes can bring up a lot of emotions, including excitement, insecurity, jealousy, or even guilt. The "empty feeling" might be your mind processing these emotions, especially if you‚Äôre still reconciling your feelings about the experience.

2. **Fear of Comparison**: If your husband was more focused on the other person during the threesome, it might have triggered feelings of insecurity or fear of being compared. Even if you‚Äôve talked about it and feel better, those emotions might resurface as you consider doing it again.

3. **Uncertainty About Boundaries**: Threesomes require clear communication and boundaries. The empty feeling could be a sign that you‚Äôre unsure about your own limits or whether this is something you truly want to pursue further.

4. **Desire vs. Reality**: You might crave the excitement or novelty of the experience but feel emotionally disconnected or uncertain about how it aligns with your relationship or personal values.

5. **Post-Experience Letdown**: After an intense or new experience, it‚Äôs common to feel a sense of emptiness or anticlimax as the adrenaline and excitement wear off.

6. **Relationship Dynamics**: Threesomes can shift the dynamics of a relationship, even temporarily. The empty feeling might be related to concerns about how this could affect your connection with your husband.

To address these feelings, consider the following steps:
- **Reflect on Your Emotions**: Journaling or talking with a trusted friend or therapist can help you unpack your feelings and identify what‚Äôs causing the emptiness.
- **Communicate with Your Husband**: Share your mixed emotions with him openly. Discuss what you both enjoyed, what felt uncomfortable, and how you can ensure everyone feels valued and secure in future experiences.
- **Set Clear Boundaries**: If you decide to explore this further, establish clear boundaries and agreements to ensure everyone feels safe and respected.
- **Take Your Time**: There‚Äôs no rush to repeat the experience. Give yourself space to process and decide what feels right for you.

Remember, it‚Äôs okay to have conflicting emotions. What matters most is that you and your husband continue to communicate openly and prioritize each other‚Äôs emotional well-being.

Context: I'm in my mid 20s with a husband and children. I love my family, but I feel like I've lost my identity, and I don't know who I am other than a mom and wife. At times, all I can think is what I gave up and how I feel unhappy and trapped, but I know I'd feel like worse without them. I loathe myself at times. I have an amazing life, so why can't I just enjoy it?
Response: It is not easy being a wife and mother. You have shifted roles in your life. You went from having a career to focusing on your family. Transitioning can be hard, especially when we feel we gave something up that we really wanted. I want to acknowledge you for wanting to be the best wife and mother you can. I think it is great that you are self-aware and want to work on this.Feeling "unhappy and trapped" may also mean that you are ¬†believing these negative thoughts are absolutely true. We have lots and lots of thoughts throughout the day. Sometimes we pay a lot of attention to some and some we ignore. Right now these thoughts are getting a lot of your attention and perhaps you are thinking because you are thinking them they are true. ¬†Is it really true that you trapped? You also said that you have an amazing life. It doesn't sound like you are only having negative thoughts. You have some positive ones, too. However, you are giving a lot of weight to the negative thoughts, more weight than the positive ones.I also wonder if you are struggling with the fact that you are even having this thought. One thing that can be helpful is to recognize that you are having a thought, that it is a negative thought, that thinking it does not make it true, and to let it go. This is the basis for mindfulness work that can be really helpful. It is a great place for you to start so you can balance out your thoughts and emotions.Best of luck to you!
Answer:
First, I want to acknowledge how brave it is for you to share these feelings. What you're experiencing is incredibly common, especially for parents and spouses who pour so much of themselves into their families. It‚Äôs okay to feel this way, and it doesn‚Äôt mean you don‚Äôt love your family or that you‚Äôre ungrateful for your life. It simply means you‚Äôre human, and you‚Äôre yearning for a sense of self beyond the roles you play.

Here are some thoughts and suggestions that might help you navigate this:

---

### 1. **Your Feelings Are Valid**
   - It‚Äôs normal to feel a sense of loss or confusion about your identity when your life revolves around caring for others. You‚Äôre not alone in this, and it doesn‚Äôt mean you‚Äôre a bad mom or wife. It just means you‚Äôre craving balance and a deeper connection with yourself.

---

### 2. **Reconnect with Your Interests**
   - Think about the things you loved before becoming a mom and wife. Were there hobbies, passions, or dreams you set aside? Even if it‚Äôs just a small step, try to reintroduce something that brings *you* joy‚Äîwhether it‚Äôs reading, painting, exercising, or learning something new.
   - If you‚Äôre not sure what you enjoy anymore, give yourself permission to explore. Try new activities and see what resonates.

---

### 3. **Carve Out Time for Yourself**
   - It‚Äôs easy to feel trapped when your time is entirely dedicated to others. Talk to your husband about creating a routine where you have regular ‚Äúme time.‚Äù Even an hour a week to focus on yourself can make a big difference.
   - If childcare is a barrier, consider asking for help from family or friends, or explore local resources like babysitting co-ops.

---

### 4. **Reframe Your Thoughts**
   - It‚Äôs natural to think about what you‚Äôve ‚Äúgiven up,‚Äù but try to shift your focus to what you‚Äôve gained and what you can still create. Your identity is not fixed‚Äîit‚Äôs evolving. You can still pursue your dreams and passions, even if it looks different now.
   - Instead of thinking, ‚ÄúI‚Äôve lost myself,‚Äù try thinking, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm rediscovering who I am in this new chapter.‚Äù

---

### 5. **Talk to Someone**
   - If these feelings persist, consider talking to a therapist or counselor. They can help you process your emotions and develop strategies to rebuild your sense of self.
   - You might also find support in mom groups or online communities where others share similar experiences.

---

### 6. **Practice Self-Compassion**
   - It‚Äôs easy to feel guilty for not being ‚Äúhappy enough,‚Äù but beating yourself up only makes things harder. Remind yourself that it‚Äôs okay to feel conflicted and that you‚Äôre doing your best.
   - Try journaling or affirmations to shift your mindset. For example, ‚ÄúI am more than my roles, and I deserve to feel fulfilled.‚Äù

---

### 7. **Involve Your Family in Your Growth**
   - Share your feelings with your husband in a way that helps him understand your needs. Let him know that taking time for yourself will ultimately make you a happier and more present partner and mom.
   - You can also involve your kids in activities that align with your interests, like crafting, cooking, or outdoor adventures. This way, you‚Äôre nurturing your identity while spending time with them.

---

### 8. **Set Small Goals**
   - Rediscovering yourself doesn‚Äôt have to happen overnight. Start with small, achievable goals, like signing up for a class, joining a book club, or setting aside 15 minutes a day for something you enjoy.

---

### 9. **Remember: You‚Äôre Not Alone**
   - Many moms and wives feel this way, even if they don‚Äôt talk about it openly. You‚Äôre not failing‚Äîyou‚Äôre navigating a challenging but common part of life.

---

### 10. **Be Patient with Yourself**
   - Rediscovering your identity is a journey, and it‚Äôs okay if it takes time. Celebrate small wins along the way and remind yourself that you‚Äôre worthy of happiness and fulfillment.

---

You‚Äôre doing an incredible job balancing so many responsibilities, but you deserve to feel like *you* again. Take it one step at a time, and know that it‚Äôs never too late to reconnect with yourself and create a life that feels fulfilling in every way. You‚Äôve got this. üíõ

Context: I am going through a very hard time and I'm so depressed. My parents are getting a divorce and a lot of bad things are happening. I want to lull myself.
Response: It sounds like a tough time and it's normal to feel down when your family is going through a divorce or other hardship. There's a difference between feelings like sadness, discouragement, grief, loneliness and depression, though. Sadness is sadness and sometimes we have to go through a grieving or other process, that is a normal reaction to events in our lives. Depression, on the other hand, is more about being stuck.¬†Lulling yourself with self-care sounds like a healthy response and a way to give yourself support. So as to the uncomfortable but healthy part of your feelings, do the best you can to put names to it and share with a trusted other person. You will find comfort.¬†The part of your situation that's depression -- feeling stuck, not able to get out of bad, concentrate, changes in sleeping and eating, loss of enjoyment in living, poor hygiene, feelings of hopelessness, that's different. First step, identify your own symptoms of depression. If you have any thoughts of hurting yourself, tell someone. If you're not sure, you can try 800-lifenet or other support line to get feedback.¬†First aid for depression includes: daily care and feeding, good sleeping and eating, lots of exercise--even when you don't feel like it--¬†healthy socializing, and focusing on talking to yourself in a positive way.
